Ms M. Xiao would like to acknowledge the Australian Government for the financial support through the Australian Government Research Training Program Scholarship. The financial support from National Science Foundation of China (No. 513228201 ) is also highly appreciated. Image, application 1 Mu Xiao obtained her master degree from Zhejiang University in 2015. She is a current Ph.D. student in AIBN Nanomaterials Centre. Her research interest is developing functional nanomaterials for photocatalysis. Dr. Bin Luo is currently UQ postdoctoral Research Fellow at the Australian institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology (AIBN), the Unversity of Queensland (UQ). He received his Ph.D. degree from National Centre for Nanoscience and Technology of China, the University of Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2013. His research interest focuses on the development of two dimensional functional nanomaterials/nanostructures for energy storage and conversion applications, including rechargeable batteries, supercapacitors and photocatalysis. Songcan Wang received his B.Eng. (2011) and M.Eng (2014) from Central South University (CSU), China. He is a current Ph.D. student under the supervision of Prof. Lianzhou Wang at School of Chemical Engineering, the University of Queensland, Australia. His research interests are mainly focused on the design and development of high performance photoanodes for Photoelectrochemical energy storage and conversion. Prof. Lianzhou Wang is the professor at the School of Chemical Engineering and the Director of Nanomaterials Center, the University of Queensland (UQ), Australia. He received his Ph.D. degree from Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1999. Before joining UQ in 2004, he has worked at two national institutes (NIMS and AIST) of Japan for five years. Wang's research interests mainly focus on the design and application of semiconducting nanomaterials in renewable energy conversion/storage systems, including photocatalysis, solar cell, rechargable Fig 14 Review Solar energy conversion on g-C3N4 photocatalyst: Light harvesting, charge separation, and surface kinetics Mu Xiao Bin Luo Songcan Wang Lianzhou Wang ⁎ Nanomaterials Centre, School of Chemical Engineering and Australian Institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology, The University of Queensland, St Lucia, QLD 4072, Australia Nanomaterials Centre School of Chemical Engineering and Australian Institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology The University of Queensland St Lucia QLD 4072 Australia ⁎ Corresponding author. Photocatalysis, which utilizes solar energy to trigger chemical reactions, is one of the most desirable solar-energy-conversion approaches. Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4), as an attractive metal-free photocatalyst, has drawn worldwide research interest in the area of solar energy conversion due to its easy synthesis, earth-abundant nature, physicochemical stability and visible-light-responsive properties. Over the past ten years, g-C3N4 based photocatalysts have experienced intensive exploration, and great progress has been achieved. However, the solar conversion efficiency is still far from industrial applications due to the wide bandgap, severe charge recombination, and lack of surface active sites. Many strategies have been proposed to enhance the light absorption, reduce the recombination of charge carriers and accelerate the surface kinetics. This work makes a crucial review about the main contributions of various strategies to the light harvesting, charge separation and surface kinetics of g-C3N4 photocatalyst. Furthermore, the evaluation measurements for the enhanced light harvesting, reduced charge recombination and accelerated surface kinetics will be discussed. In addition, this review proposes future trends to enhance the photocatalytic performance of g-C3N4 photocatalyst for the solar energy conversion. Graphical abstract Artificial photosynthesis based on g-C3N4 catalyst faces several bottlenecks: weak light harvesting, severe charge recombination, and slow surface kinetics. How to better design g-C3N4 photocatalyst for highly efficient solar energy conversion is an open question. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Photocatalysis g-C3N4 Light harvesting Charge separation Surface kinetics Solar energy conversion 1 Introduction Due to the explosion of population and industrialization, humans are currently facing the global energy shortage and environmental problems. It is necessary to explore and develop sustainable and green energy system. Solar energy, which is a type of free, clean, abundant, and renewable energy on earth, is a fascinating gift from nature. However, the solar energy cannot be used as industrial and domestic energy supply directly due to its discontinuity and instability. Thus, tremendous attention have been focused on the area of solar energy conversion [1–4]. Photocatalysis, which stores solar energy into chemical bonds, exhibits high potential for solar energy conversion. Since the pioneering work from Fujishima and Honda in 1970s [5], the whole world shows dramatically increasing interest in the photocatalysis [6–8], which can be confirmed by the exponential increase of annual publications in this area [9]. Photocatalysis mainly includes water splitting for hydrogen (H2) generation [10], reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2) for solar energy generation [11], degradation of pollutant [12] and organic synthesis [13], of which the basic mechanism is the same. Taking semiconducting photocatalyst as an example, the electrons jump up to the conduction band (CB) while holes generate in the valence band (VB) under light irradiation, and then they transfer to the surface of photocatalyst for redox reaction (Fig. 1 a). During the charge transfer, photo-excited electron-hole pairs easily recombine and lower the solar energy conversion efficiency. The whole photocatalytic reaction is a six-step process, including absorption of photon, separation of exciton, diffusion of carrier, transport of carrier, catalytic reaction and transfer of mass. The six processes are in different time scales, varying from femtosecond to microsecond (Fig. 1b) [14]. The photocatalytic reaction is the synergistic effect of the six processes. Apparently, the six processes can be briefly divided into three main steps: light absorption, charge separation and transport, and surface reaction. To achieve high solar energy conversion efficiency, the photocatalyst should meet three requirements. First, the photocatalyst should be visible-light responsive, because more than 45% of sunlight is visible light [14]. Second, the photocatalyst should show good electric conductivity, otherwise the photo-excited electron-hole pairs may recombine during the transport process (Fig. 1a). Third, the surface of the photocatalyst should be active for the redox reaction. Thus, the development of efficient photocatalysts is mainly focused on three aspects: enhancing light harvesting, reducing charge recombination, and accelerating surface kinetics. Since the first report about photocatalysis, many materials have been exploited as photocatalysts for solar energy conversion [6]. Among them, titanium dioxide (TiO2) has been investigated mostly, because of its low-cost, long-term stability and environment friendly [15]. However, the bandgap of TiO2 is around 3.2 eV, making it active only under UV light (4% of sunlight) illumination [16]. In order to achieve highly efficient solar energy conversion, many visible-light-responsive materials such as metal sulphide, metal (oxy)nitride, and solid solution have been developed as photocatalysts [6]. Some of them show high solar energy conversion efficiency, but they suffer from self-oxidation during the photocatalytic reaction and harm the long-term stability. In 2009, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) polymer was demonstrated as a non-metal photocatalyst for solar H2 production under visible light [17]. Due to its easy synthesis, earth-abundant nature, physicochemical stability and visible-light-responsive property, this photocatalyst drew worldwide research interest immediately. Since the first report in 2009, the annual publications and citations about g-C3N4 photocatalyst increased dramatically [9]. Based on the in-depth research, there has been a more comprehensive understanding about this photocatalyst over time. Although g-C3N4 is visible-light-responsive, the relative wide bandgap limits its light absorption to around 460 nm, which is only a small amount of visible light. In addition, the organic semiconductors usually produce Frenkel excitons under light irradiation. The Frenkel excitons possess high binding energy, which means low dissociation probabilities and leads to serious charge recombination [18,19]. The last but not the least, the surface of g-C3N4 lack active sites for redox reaction, which results in a low probability of surface reaction for the photogenerated charge carriers [17]. Around these issues, tremendous attention has been devoted into the development of g-C3N4 photocatalyst and great progress has been achieved. Many chemical strategies, including morphology control, doping, defects control, heterojunctions, and co-catalysts have explored to improve the photocatalytic activity [20–22]. Up to date, there have been some interesting reviews on g-C3N4, which described the history, property, synthesis techniques, possible applications and strategies of improving the photocatalytic performance [9,23–29]. However, considering the fast development of this area, a critical review focusing on the contributions of various chemical strategies to the photocatalytic process is lacking to provide the readers with a whole picture of the recent progress in this field. In order to better design the g-C3N4 photocatalyst for efficient solar energy conversion, it is of great importance to clarify the influence of those strategies to the photocatalytic activity. Herein, we make a critical review on the main contributions of those strategies to the light absorption, charge separation and transport, and surface kinetics. Furthermore, the evaluation measurements for the enhanced absorption of light, reduced recombination of charge carriers and accelerated surface kinetics have been discussed. It is believed that an in-depth understanding of various strategies should be a guidance to make those strategies cooperate with each other and achieve highly efficient solar energy conversion in the future. 2 Enhanced light harvesting Light harvesting is the first step for photocatalytic activity, which determines the maximum of solar energy conversion efficiency [6]. During the light harvesting, photocatalyst absorbs photons and produce electro-hole pairs. Typically, electrons in the VB jump to the CB and holes leave in the VB. Thus, only photons with energy equal or larger than the bandgap energy of photocatalyst can be utilized for charge carriers’ generation. The relationship between band gap of photocatalyst and wavelength (λ) of sunlight can be descript by Eq. (1) [6]: (1) Band gap ( eV ) = 1240 / λ ( nm ) For example, the absorption edge of g-C3N4 photocatalyst with ∼ 2.7 eV bandgap should be around 460 nm. Another important point is the bandgap position of the photocatalyst. Here we take the photocatalytic water splitting and CO2 reduction as examples. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), the position of CB should be more negative than the H+/H2 reduction potential (NHE) while the VB should be more positive than the O2/H2O oxidation potential [14]. As for CO2 reduction, the position of CB determines the final products, varying from –0.24 V for CH4 to –0.61 V for HCOOH (Fig. 2b) [30]. Considering the light harvesting, the bandgap of photocatalyst should be as narrow as possible once the bandgap straddles the redox potentials. The CB and VB of g-C3N4 are around –0.9 eV and 1.8 eV vs. NHE respectively, which means that g-C3N4 photocatalyst is capable of CO2 reduction and water splitting. However, the relative wide bandgap of g-C3N4 make it harvest only a small amount of sunlight, leading to a relatively low solar energy conversion efficiency. In the area of photocatalysis, doping is an efficient approach to tune the bandgap of photocatalyst, namely bandgap engineering [31]. Hitherto, numerous research works about the element doping of g-C3N4 have been demonstrated to narrow the bandgap [9]. Both cations and anions, such as zinc (Zn), iron (Fe), boron (B), carbon (C), nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), oxygen (O), sulphur (S), fluorine (F), iodine (I), have been extensively investigated [27,32–44]. Here, we just take several typical examples to analyse and discuss the influence of doping on the light harvesting, thus improving the performance of the g-C3N4 photocatalyst. Zn doped g-C3N4, which showed enhanced harvesting, was prepared by a simple soft-chemical method [40]. The improved visible light absorption was evidenced by the UV-vis diffuse absorption spectra. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), Zn doped g-C3N4 with varying doping concentration (x%-Zn/C3N4, x is the weight percent of Zn precursor to g-C3N4) exhibited higher light absorption intensity and longer absorption edge compared with g-C3N4. The red-shift of the absorption edge was attributed to the d-p repulsion of the N 2p and Zn 3d orbitals, which has been reported in other metal (oxy)nitride materials [45,46]. In addition, the absorption edge of Zn/C3N4 was prolonged with increasing Zn doping concentration. The photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4 and Zn/C3N4 was explored by photocatalytic H2 evolution. Zn/C3N4 with varying Zn doping concentration exhibited higher H2 evolution rate than g-C3N4. In particular, 10%-Zn/C3N4 showed the highest H2 evolution rate, which was 10 times higher than tg-C3N4. Due to the enhanced light harvesting, an apparent quantum efficiency of 3.2% (420 nm)was achieved. Another good example is the S doped g-C3N4, which is prepared by adopting thiourea as the sulphur source [47]. The sulphur dopant was detected as S2− to substitute N atom and formed C–S bond in the g-C3N4 by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The S-doped g-C3N4 with different S concentrations was denoted as CNSx (x meant the weight percent of S precursor vs. g-C3N4). Similar to the Zn-doped g-C3N4, the CNSx exhibited enhancing visible light absorption with increasing S doping concentration (Fig. 4 a). As expected, the CNSx samples showed improved photocatalytic H2 evolution activity compared with undoped g-C3N4 (Fig. 4b and c). Among various samples, the CNS 10 exhibited the best H2 evolution activity of 12.16 µmol h−1, which was ∼ 6 times higher than undoped g-C3N4. The possible mechanism between enhanced light harvesting and improved photocatalytic performance was investigated and proposed (Fig. 4d). The XPS and UV-vis diffuse reflection spectra results demonstrated that S-doping could narrow the bandgap of g-C3N4, leading to enhanced the visible light absorption. According to the theoretical simulation results about the bandgap structure of S-doped g-C3N4, a new energy level occupied by electrons formed above the VB due to the interaction of N 2p states and S 3p states, thus narrowing the bandgap [37]. The narrower bandgap resulted in enhanced light harvesting and increased photo-excited electrons and holes for redox reaction, then improving the photocatalytic performance. Noticeably, an optimal doping concentration exists for both Zn-doped and S-doped g-C3N4. As shown in Figs. 3(a) and 4(a), the samples exhibited enhanced light harvesting with increasing doping concentration. However, the photocatalytic activity did not show the same tendency. For S-doped g-C3N4, the position of the new energy level elevated with increasing doping concentration, which acted as recombination centers and lowered the photocatalytic activity (Fig. 4d). Every coin has two sides. On one hand, doping can narrow the bandgap by creating new energy level below the CB or above the VB, which means that more photons can be used to produce electrons and holes for redox reaction [48–50]. On the other hand, the new energy level acts as recombination center and the generated charge carriers have less possibility to take part in the redox reaction due to the lower reduction or oxidation potential [50–52]. Thus, a contest exists between the enhanced light harvesting and increased charge recombination. For an optimal doping concentration, the dopants mainly contribute to the enhanced light harvesting, thus improving the photocatalytic activity. When further increasing the doping amount, the dopants mainly act as recombination centers. Consequently, a proper doping concentration is essential to the photocatalytic activity. In addition to element doping, the introduction of defects into g-C3N4 is another efficient strategy to tune the electronic structure and optical property [53–55]. Niu et al. successfully introduced N vacancies (N v ) into g-C3N4 by controlling the polymerization temperature of dicyandiamide precursor [56]. XPS indicated that the N v mainly formed at the N2c lattice sites during the thermal condensation (Fig. 5 a). The obtained Nv-rich g-C3N4 exhibited extended visible light harvesting, which was evidenced by the UV-visible light absorption spectra (Fig. 5b). As a result, the photocatalytic performance was significantly improved. Later, the same group developed a new type of g-C3N4 (melon) modified by homogeneous N v , which was achieved by a thermal treatment under H2 atmosphere [57]. It was believed that the H2 reduced N atoms into NH3 at high temperature, which resulted in the nitrogen vacancies. According to the theoretical calculation, the N2 is the most likely to be reduced among the four non-equivalent N atoms (Fig. 5c and d). The UV-visible absorption spectroscopy showed that the absorption edge of the resulted materials shifted to 850 nm, corresponding to a bandgap of 2.03 eV (Fig. 5e). The g-C3N4 modified with homogeneous N v showed a much more excellent photocatalytic activity than the original melon. Liu et al. reported similar result by choosing NaBH4 as the hydrogen source [58]. The color of the powder changed from yellow to brown, leading to increased visible light absorption and much narrower bandgap from 2.75 eV to 2.00 eV. As can be seen, the N v at different positions exhibit totally different influences on the electronic structure and light harvesting ability of g-C3N4. Generally, the surface defects prefer to produce some localized states in the band structure of photocatalyst, which only lead to an absorption trailer at the light absorption spectra (Fig. 5b). However, the homogeneous defects can modify the band structure of photocatalyst more thoroughly and result in a whole shift of UV-vis absorption spectra (Fig. 5e) [37,59–61]. Considering the essential effect of the electronic structure on photocatalyst, homogeneous defects should be pursued in the future. Apart from atomic defects, the break of long-range atomic order can also tune the electronic structures of materials. Recently, Kang et al. reported the amorphous carbon nitride (ACN) which showed much different properties compared with crystalline g-C3N4 (GCN). Kang et al. firstly examined the possibility by ab initio molecular dynamics simulation, and the GCN preferred to disorder after annealing at 900 K in vacuum for 4 ps [62]. Based on this result, the ACN had been obtained by heating the GCN at 897 K under argon atmosphere for a certain period. Compared with the GCN, the absorption edge of ACN shifted from 460 nm to 682 nm, which led to a much narrower bandgap of 1.90 eV (Fig. 6 a). The ACN showed a complete shift of absorption spectra, indicating a homogeneous structure modification. According to the XPS results, the narrower bandgap was caused by the positive shift of CB and negative shift of VB by 0.61 eV and 0.31 eV (Fig. 6b), which indicated that the ACN were still capable of water redox reactions. Due to the enhanced light harvesting, the ACN showed more than 12 times of photocatalytic H2 evolution rate (Fig. 6c). To further confirm the contribution of enhanced light harvesting to the photocatalytic performance, the authors checked the photocatalytic H2 generation with different wavelengths. The ACN showed photocatalytic activity at 600 nm, which meant that the enhanced light harvesting really contributed to the photocatalytic performance. Consequently, for the light harvesting study in the future, two important issues should be taken into consideration. First, the mechanism of narrowed bandgap should be clarified to identify the redox potential of photo-generated electrons and holes. Several optical and electrochemical methods can be adopted to identify the bandgap position of photocatalysts, such as XPS, ultraviolet photoelectron spectrometer (UPS), kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM), and depth-resolved cathodoluminescence spectroscopy (DRCLS) [63,64]. Another important issue is the contribution of enhanced light harvesting to the photocatalytic activity. Whether the absorbed light has been used to generate electron-hole pairs and take part in the redox reaction need to be confirmed. Thus, photocatalytic activity should be conducted under light wavelength around the light absorption edge. 3 Reduced charge recombination Apart from the light absoprtion, charge separation and transfer is another factor that influences the photocatalytic activity. After light absorption, electron-hole pairs are generated and then transferred to the surface to take part in the redox reaction. During the transfer process, the charge carriers are easy to recombine with each other thus lowering the solar conversion efficiency. To solve this problem, tremendous efforts have been focused on shortening the charge transfer distance and enhancing the electric conductivity of g-C3N4. Over the past years, many strategies have been adopted to reduce the charge recombination of g-C3N4 photocatalyst, such as nanostructure, in-plane junction, homojunction, heterojunction [58,65–70]. Constructing nanostructure is a general strategy to shorten the charge transport distance thus suppressing the charge recombination [71–73]. g-C3N4 with a layered structure, has been exfoliated into graphene-like nanosheets through physical or chemical methods because of the weak van der Waals forces connecting the layers [9]. Niu et al. reported a facile thermal oxidation etching method to exfoliate bulk g-C3N4 into g-C3N4 nanosheets with a thickness of ∼ 2 nm (Fig. 7 a) [74]. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the g-C3N4 nanosheets showed relatively lower decay kinetics and longer lifetime of photo-excited charge carriers compared with bulk g-C3N4, indicating reduced charge recombination. Due to quantum confinement effect, there was a significant blue-shift for the UV-vis absorption spectra of g-C3N4 nanosheets (Fig. 7c). The increased lifetime of charge carriers was attributed to a better electron transport and the change of band structure caused by the quantum confinement effect. As expected, the g-C3N4 nanosheets showed much better photocatalytic activity than that of the bulk g-C3N4. Apart from nanosheets, other nanostructures such as hollow spheres, nanotubes, seaweed architecture and porous nanosheets have been prepared, which exhibited improved photocatalytic activity [68,75–77]. Due to the incomplete polymerization of the precursor with amine groups, large amount of H bonds exist in the layered g-C3N4, which connect the melon units and form the long-range atomic order. Compared with the strong bonds in the melon units, the charge transfer through the penal with weak hydrogen bonds should be hindered. To solve this problem, Kang et al. selectively broke the hydrogen bonds of layered g-C3N4 by heating the g-C3N4 at different temperatures under argon atmosphere for a certain period [78]. As expected, the resulted products exhibited better electronic conductivity, which had been confirmed by the photodeposition of Au nanoparticles (Fig. 8 ). For the pristine g-C3N4, the Au particles only appeared on some part and the particle size was up to 200 nm. After selectively breaking the hydrogen bonds, the Au particles had been coated uniformly on the g-C3N4 and the particle size was around 10 nm. As a result, the g-C3N4 with broken hydrogen bonds showed a 35 times higher photocatalytic H2 evolution rate than the of the pristine g-C3N4. Inspired by the organic solar cell, in which the efficiency can be improved by copolymerizing donor-acceptor structure, Che et al. constructed Cring-C3N4 heterostructural nanosheets through the copolymerization of glucose and melamine [67]. The in-planar Cring-C3N4 heterostructure was prepared by a two-step thermal condensation, as shown in Fig. 9 (a). Due to the similar structure, the Cring-containing glucose and melem units were connected by the sp 2-hybridized C–N bonds between them at around 673 K. Later, the in-planar g-C3N4 heterostructure formed via π-conjugated bonds by further polymerization at 823 K. A local electric field formed between the Cring and g-C3N4, which remarkably favor the charge separation and transfer (Fig. 9b). The improved conductivity of photo-generated charge carriers was confirmed by the electrochemical impedance measurement (Fig. 9c). Furthermore, the calculated charge diffusion lengths were significantly enhanced by 10 times compared with pristine g-C3N4, inferring accelerated charge transfer kinetics. As a result, the Cring-C3N4 heterostructure realized efficient photocatalytic overall water splitting and achieved an apparent quantum efficiency of 5% (420 nm) (Fig. 9d). In addition to in-planar modification, the construction of heterojunction by combining two photocatalysts with appropriate bandgap structures is another efficient strategy to reduce the charge recombination [6,79–83]. Based on this, the construction of g-C3N4 based heterojunctions has been intensively explored [84–90]. As the bandgaps of g-C3N4 from different precursors are different, Dong et al. constructed a type I heterojunction with a mixed precursor of melamine and urea [91]. The CB of g-C3N4 from urea (CN-U) is 0.17 eV higher than that of g-C3N4 from melamine (CN-M), while the VB of CN-U is ∼0.17 eV lower than that of CN-M. The formation of inner-electric-field made the electrons of CN-U transfer to CN-M and holes leave in CN-U, thus separating the photo-excited charge carriers (Fig. 10 a). Type II heterojunctions can also be constructed with a mixed precursor of dicyandiamide and urea (Fig. 10b). As a result, the type I and type II g-C3N4 based heterojunction from mixed precursors showed improved photocatalytic activity compared with the g-C3N4 from single precursor. In addition, the carbon materials show good electric conductivity, wide-range light absorption, and long-term stability in aqueous solution, which will favor the photocatalytic activity of photocatalysts. More importantly, the carbon materials are earth-abundant and easily prepared, which make it one of the best choices to modify photocatalysts [92–97]. As the g-C3N4 is a kind of polymeric semiconductor, it can easily combine with carbon materials, including carbon nanotubes (CNTs), graphene and carbon quantum dots (CQDs) [98–100] . Recently, the combination of g-C3N4 with some kinds of polymeric semiconductors as photocatalysts for solar energy conversion has also been explored, such as graphitized polyacrylonitrile, poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene), polypyrrole, and poly(3-hexylthiophene) [101–105]. Among them, an apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) of 2.9% has been achieved on the heterojunction of g-C3N4 and poly(3hexylthiophene). The moderate performance was attributed to the insufficient light harvesting and inefficient charge separation. Thus, more research efforts have been dedicated to further improve the efficiency. Very recently, Chen et al. reported polymeric heterojunctions consisting of polyfluorence family polymers and g-C3N4 for highly efficient solar hydrogen generation [106]. As shown in Fig. 11 (a), the poly(9,9-dioctylfluorene((PFO) formed heterojunction with g-C3N4 through the intermolecular π-π interaction. A molecular modification strategy was proposed by the authors to further improve the charge separation or light absorption. It was found that integrating electron-accepting benzothiadiazole or electron-donating carbazole unit into the PFO framework could effectively tune its electronic structure. As a result, poly(N-decanyl-2,7-carbazole-alt-9,9-dioctylfluorene) (PCzF) and poly(9,9-dioctylfluorene-alt-benzothiadiazole) (PTFB) were obtained through the molecular modification. A negative shift occurred for the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of PCzF, which made more efficient charge separation for the heterojunction due to the stronger inner-electric field (Fig. 11b). On the other hand, PTFB showed a narrower bandgap by 0.5 eV, which largely improved the visible light absorption of the heterojunction (Fig. 11c). For photocatalytic H2 evolution, AQEs of 27% at 440 nm over PCzF/g-C3N4 and 13% at 500 nm over PTFB/g-C3N4 have been achieved respectively. Those studies demonstrate that the formation of inner-electric field by constructing heterojunction is an efficient way to promote the charge separation and suppress the charge recombination of g-C3N4, thus promoting the photocatalytic performance. Another efficient strategy to reduce the charge recombination is the Z-scheme system. As shown in Fig. 12 , various materials have been combined with g-C3N4 to form Z-scheme system for water splitting, CO2 reduction, and organic synthesis [69,83,107,108]. The basic mechanism of Z-scheme system has been descripted by Zhou et al.; here we just take α-Fe2O3/g-C3N4 system as an example [109]. Under light irradiation, charge carriers generate in both α-Fe2O3 and g-C3N4. The electrons on g-C3N4 are used to produce H2, while the holes of g-C3N4 recombine with the electrons from α-Fe2O3. In addition, the holes left on α-Fe2O3 are used for oxidation reaction. Unlike the heterojunction, which will reduce the redox potential of photo-excited charge carriers, the Z-scheme system reduce the charge recombination but maintain the redox potential of both materials. The bandgap structures and interface between the two materials play crucial role in the formation of efficient Z-scheme system, although the formation mechanism is still unclear [109]. Several optical and electrochemical methods, including photoluminescence (PL), Time-resolved infra-red spectroscopy (TRIR) and Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) have been demonstrated to be effective for the measurement of reduced charge recombination [65,66,74,110,111]. Time-resolved fluorescence decay spectra and fluorescence emission spectra can be collected from PL. The former one indicates the radical recombination of photo-excited charge carriers, of which the lower intensity means the suppression of radical recombination. The lifetime of photo-generated electrons can be obtained from time-resolved fluorescence decay spectra. The longer lifetime means the reduced recombination and the charge carriers have higher possibility to take part in the surface reactions [74]. The function of TRIR is similar to the time-resolved fluorescence decay spectra. EIS is an electrochemical method to measure the electric conductivity of materials. Better conductivity means improved charge transfer and probably less charge recombination. However, it is not convenient for the photocatalyst in powder form to take the EIS test. Because an electrode is necessary to take this test, which means the powder need to be loaded on conductive substrate and keep a good contact with the substrate [67]. Further exploration of convenient and effective measurements for the charge recombination should be helpful to the development of photocatalysis. 4 Accelerated surface kinetics The last step of photocatalysis is the surface reaction. After light harvesting, electrons and holes generate, and then separate and transfer to the surface for redox reactions. It has been demonstrated that the surface of g-C3N4 showed low activity for water splitting or CO2 reduction [9,17]. The accumulation of charge carriers on the surface not only increase the charge recombination, but also damage the long-term stability of photocatalyst [112,113]. It was found that certain kind of catalyst loaded on the surface of photocatalyst, namely co-catalyst, could significantly accelerate the surface kinetics [114]. Various co-catalysts have been loaded on g-C3N4 to promote the surface redox reactions, which can be divided into several types according to their functions. For example, Pt [17], MoS2 [115], NiS [116,117], Ni(OH)2 act as H2 evolution catalyst (HEC) [118], while Co(OH)2 acts as oxygen evolution catalyst (OEC). Furthermore, single site Co-based co-catalyst triggered overall water splitting on g-C3N4, which means that it acts as both HEC and OEC [119]. In addition, Co3O4 [120], CoS [121], Pt [122] and Mg-Al layered double hydroxide (LDH) [123] act as CO2 reduction catalyst. General, Pt is the mostly used co-catalyst for photocatalytic H2 evolution [124–127]. Due to the limited amount of Pt on earth, other HEC has been intensively explored to replace Pt [128,129]. Among them, MoS2, exhibiting efficient hydrogen evolution for both photocatalytic and electrocatalytic water splitting, has been regarded as a potential candidate [130]. In particular, both MoS2 and g-C3N4 have layered structure, which should reduce the lattice mismatch and facilitate the growth of planar MoS2 on the g-C3N4 surface. Hou et al. reported a layered nanojunctions consisting of MoS2 and g-C3N4 for photocatalytic H2 evolution [115]. Compared to Pt as HEC, the MoS2/g-C3N4 exhibited much better performance with the same loading amount. It was believed that geometric similarity facilitated the growth of thin layer MoS2 on the g-C3N4 surface and the formation of planar MoS2/g-C3N4 interface, which promoted the photocatalytic performance. However, the MoS2 suffered from the oxidation/corrosion by the photo-excited holes, which directly destroyed its long-term stability. The loading of OEC should be desirable to consume the holes efficiently and protected the MoS2 from photo-corrosion. To deposit both HEC and OEC on a single photocatalyst, the main problem is how to separate them spatially. Zheng et al. solved this problem by preparing a hollow carbon nitride structure (HCNS) [131]. The Pt (HEC) was deposited on the inner shell of HCNS while the Co3O4 (OEC) was loaded on the outer shell of HCNS, thus successfully separating the two co-catalysts (Fig. 13 a). Compared with the mixed co-catalysts, the separated co-catalysts significantly improve the water splitting efficiency. Very recently, Liu et al. designed a single Co1-P4 site confined on g-C3N4 nanosheets for efficient photocatalytic water splitting [119]. The Co1 OXO/g-C3N4 was firstly obtained through a simple pyrolysis method. Then the Co1-phosphide composite formed via a phosphidation under PH3 atmosphere. The presence of single Co atom was verified by the atomic-resolution high-angle-annular-dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) measurement. It was demonstrated that the coordinatively unsaturated Co site could significantly suppress the photo-excited charge recombination, thus prolonging the carrier lifetime by 20 times. In addition, the Co site could promote water molecular adsorption and activate oxygen evolution. As shown in Fig. 13(b), the photo-excited electrons and holes were spatially separated. Consequently, the single-site co-catalyst/g-C3N4 achieved photocatalytic overall water splitting with an AQE of 2.2% at 500 nm. This work not only demonstrated a good example of low-cost co-catalysts for photocatalytic overall water splitting, but the potential of single-site species as efficient co-catalysts for solar energy conversion. Different from water splitting with only H2 and O2 as the products, the products for CO2 reduction are various, including HCOOH, CO, HCHO, CH3OH and CH4 and so on. The co-catalysts for CO2 reduction not only promote the conversion efficiency, but also affect the type of final products [132]. Gao et al. investigated the products of photocatalytic CO2 reduction on single atom Pt or palladium (Pd)/g-C3N4 composites via theoretical simulations [133]. It was found that the single metal atom was active site while g-C3N4 provided hydrogen (H*) from the H2 evolution reaction. CH4 and HCOOH were the preferred products of CO2 reduction on Pt/g-C3N4 and Pd/g-C3N4 photocatalytic systems, respectively. These findings proposed a new strategy to design and develop the co-catalysts for highly efficient solar energy conversion. Apart from co-catalyst, the surface environment of photocatalyst also has crucial influence on the absorption/activation and reduction of CO2 [134,135]. For example, potassium hydroxide (KOH) decorated g-C3N4 was reported to show enhanced photocatalytic CO2 reduction performance [136]. Compared with the original g-C3N4, the KOH decorated g-C3N4 exhibited a three times higher CO2 reduction rate (Fig. 14 a). It was found that the hydroxide ion (OH−) not only acted as a hole accepter, but also helped to maintain dynamical stability of the H2CO3 amount on the surface of g-C3N4 (Fig. 14b). Relatively, the surface kinetics is the most complex part of photocatalytic process. Up to date, the mechanism of surface kinetics has not been clarified, especially for the CO2 reduction. Both surface states and surface environment (e.g. pH value) have essential impact on the surface kinetics [135]. Slow surface reactions will limit the solar energy conversion even if the photocatalyst shows efficient light absorption and charge transfer. In order to accelerate surface kinetics of g-C3N4 photocatalyst, more efforts should be devoted into revealing the mechanism of surface reactions. 5 Conclusion and perspective In summary, the g-C3N4 is regarded as the next generation of photocatalysts for solar energy conversion because of its easy synthesis, earth-abundant nature, physicochemical stability and visible-light-responsive property. As a photocatalyst, the g-C3N4 has various applications, such as water splitting, reduction of CO2, degradation of pollutant, bacterial disinfection. However, the relative wide bandgap limits its light absorption, and the photo-generated excitons suffer from serious charge recombination because of high binding energy. In addition, the surface of g-C3N4 lacks active sites for redox reaction. Since the first report, tremendous efforts have been focused on those issues to improve the performance of g-C3N4 based photocatalysts. Many strategies, such as morphology control, doping, defect control, copolymerization, heterojunction and co-catalyst design have been proposed to enhance the light harvesting, reduce the charge recombination and accelerate the surface kinetics. Up to date, great progress has been achieved on g-C3N4 based photocatalyst. Molecular design of g-C3N4 should be an efficient strategy for the bandgap engineering, thus increasing the light absorption. The bandgap of g-3N4 has been narrowed to 1.9 eV, which is narrow enough to harvest most of the visible light. Construction of in-planar junction and Z-scheme system between g-C3N4 and other semiconductors has been demonstrated to be effective to reduce the charge recombination. Photocatalytic overall water splitting has been achieved through the proper design of co-catalyst. Moreover, single-site species showed high potential as co-catalysts for efficient photocatalytic reactions. However, the present solar-energy-conversion-efficiency is still moderate. Considering the synergetic effect of light absorption, charge carriers separation and transport, and surface kinetics during photocatalytic process, more research attention should be paid to the combination of various strategies which could enhance the light harvesting, suppress the recombination of charge carriers and accelerate the surface kinetics at the same time. It is expected to realize the industrial application of g-C3N4 photocatalyst due to the persistent research interest. Moreover, the mechanism understanding and knowledge obtained by studying this photocatalyst will pave a brick for the development of photocatalysis or even catalysis in the future. She is a current Ph.D. student in AIBN Nanomaterials Centre. Her research interest is developing functional nanomaterials for photocatalysis. Dr. Bin Luo is currently UQ postdoctoral Research Fellow at the Australian institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology (AIBN), the Unversity of Queensland (UQ). He received his Ph.D. degree from National Centre for Nanoscience and Technology of China, the University of Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2013. His research interest focuses on the development of two dimensional functional nanomaterials/nanostructures for energy storage and conversion applications, including rechargeable batteries, supercapacitors and photocatalysis. Songcan Wang received his B.Eng. (2011) and M.Eng (2014) from Central South University (CSU), China. He is a current Ph.D. student under the supervision of Prof. Lianzhou Wang at School of Chemical Engineering, the University of Queensland, Australia. His research interests are mainly focused on the design and development of high performance photoanodes for Photoelectrochemical energy storage and conversion. Prof. Lianzhou Wang is the professor at the School of Chemical Engineering and the Director of Nanomaterials Center, the University of Queensland (UQ), Australia. He received his Ph.D. degree from Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1999. Before joining UQ in 2004, he has worked at two national institutes (NIMS and AIST) of Japan for five years. Wang's research interests mainly focus on the design and application of semiconducting nanomaterials in renewable energy conversion/storage systems, including photocatalysis, solar cell, rechargable batteries and so on.

coredata.dc:description: Photocatalysis, which utilizes solar energy to trigger chemical reactions, is one of the most desirable solar-energy-conversion approaches. Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4), as an attractive metal-free photocatalyst, has drawn worldwide research interest in the area of solar energy conversion due to its easy synthesis, earth-abundant nature, physicochemical stability and visible-light-responsive properties. Over the past ten years, g-C3N4 based photocatalysts have experienced intensive exploration, and great progress has been achieved. However, the solar conversion efficiency is still far from industrial applications due to the wide bandgap, severe charge recombination, and lack of surface active sites. Many strategies have been proposed to enhance the light absorption, reduce the recombination of charge carriers and accelerate the surface kinetics. This work makes a crucial review about the main contributions of various strategies to the light harvesting, charge separation and surface kinetics of g-C3N4 photocatalyst. Furthermore, the evaluation measurements for the enhanced light harvesting, reduced charge recombination and accelerated surface kinetics will be discussed. In addition, this review proposes future trends to enhance the photocatalytic performance of g-C3N4 photocatalyst for the solar energy conversion.
